Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a special release of the video of the same name (see my review of _When the Forest Ran Red_ VHS). However, this version has about 10 minutes of extra footage. The DVD focuses on the early part of the French and Indian War, most specifically on little-known, but important, Braddock's Defeat. Within this time frame, we follow George Washington and learn of his many mistakes and watch him grow as a leader. We see how Washington gained valuable experience in leadership and warfare that would serve him as leader of the Revolutionary forces. I was also interested to hear of the various native tribes as participants in the war with their own geo-political goals and aspirations and not just as pawns of the British or French.The presentation is great and the information is interesting and important for an understanding of early American history. There are pictures, reenactments, and comments from scholars and historians. I was happy to see that a British historian was included. I give this documentary my highest recommendation.
summary: Fantastic DVD on French and Indian War!

reviewerName: John M. Heimerl "John HEIMERL, fequent reader"
reviewText: Buyers should be aware that this is not actually a "movie", but a narrated reenactment. It made me feel I was back in grade school. Still, evenso, it retained much of the wonderment that I felt with the school movies and the action and pretty guns going off. If you watched Last of the Mohicans, or Drums along the Mohawk, you will be disappointed when you come to this. It is nicely done, but not tops.

reviewText: This was a very good production chronicling General Edward Braddock's failed campaign of 1755.  In addition to a detailed analysis of what actually happened at the Battle of the Monongahela, I thought the program expertly explained the events leading up to the battle as well.  The tale is told with re-enactments, quotes from period sources (e.g. George Washington's letters) and, because photography didn't yet exist, artwork depicting various events and people central to the story.Along with the main program the DVD also includes a "making of" feature, an interview with a period historian, and even some "deleted scenes."  Overall a well-done presentation of the first major battle of the French and Indian War.Four stars.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this movie thinking it was going to show lots of fighting action between the Indians and early American settlers, but it turned out to be more of a documentary.  It was interesting nevertheless because it showed how the Indians manipulated a young continental officer (George Washington) into starting the French and Indian War.  To me it is amazing that George Washington never won a battle during the French and Indian War, yet was appointed by the Continental Congress to lead the army during the American Revolution. If you are more interested in history than action, this movie is for you.

reviewText: This was definitely more of an educational documentary. Still worth watching and very factual, it covers the French and Indian wars roots. It talks about Fort Necessity and the massacre at Fort DuQuense. I found the PBS documentary "The War the Made America" much more engaging and entertaining. It also covered more ground. Again, this was a good DVD but I would watch the PBS one again before I would watch this one.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a good documentary showing the beginnings of the French & Indian War.  It discusses an inexperienced George Washington and his Virginia Militia going into the Ohio Valley with their Indian Half King ally to confront the French in this disputed area.The massacre of the French precipitated the war here.The British General, Braddock, then is defeated soon afterward in this area, too.This is a well-done PBS documentary.  If you had to choose only one documentary, however, I would suggest you consider "The War That Made America," another by PBS, as it goes much deeper into not only these beginnings of the war, but continues onward from there."When the Forest Ran Red" is a single DVD, and restricts itself to only a couple of actions within this region of the country.  For a single-period classroom, it is good.  It's rival, "The War That Made America," is a 2-disc set, and is 4 episodes plus panel discussions in length.Both DVD sets include valuable discussions by knowledgeable historians.
